hints.content: Start by understanding how to extract the digits from the four-digit number. You can convert the number to a string or use arithmetic operations to isolate each digit.
Once you have the digits, think about how to distribute them into two new numbers. Each digit must be used exactly once, and leading zeros are allowed.
Consider how the arrangement of digits affects the sum of the two new numbers. For example, placing smaller digits in higher place values will yield smaller results.
Try sorting the digits in ascending order. This can help you visualize how to pair them effectively to minimize the sum.
After sorting, think about how you can alternate the digits between the two new numbers. For instance, if you have digits [a, b, c, d], you could form new1 from a and c, and new2 from b and d.
Remember that leading zeros are allowed. This means that if one of your new numbers starts with zero, it is still valid. Consider how this might affect your combinations.
Calculate the sum of the two new numbers after forming them. You can do this using simple addition once you have defined the two numbers.
Keep track of the minimum sum you encounter as you test different combinations. You might want to initialize a variable to store the minimum sum found.
Consider edge cases, such as when all digits are the same (e.g., num = 1111) or when there are leading zeros (e.g., num = 4009). How do these cases affect your logic?
To finalize your approach, ensure you are iterating through all possible pairs of new1 and new2 formed from the digits. Look for a systematic way to ensure you don't miss any combinations.

questionNotes: The number consists of exactly four digits.
All digits must be used in forming new1 and new2.
Leading zeros are allowed in new1 and new2.
